ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A thorough improvement to my understanding of the humanities thought process, which involved thorough reading and research, openness to alternative readings, active preparation and participation in discussions and synthesis in the form of discussions and papers.

I learned the skill of how to closely read ambiguous texts that deal with difficult questions on race, feminism, and class. Most importantly, this class helped me to learn how to question the authors I read and my own assumptions. Ultimately, this class helped me to see issues from a variety of lenses I've never considered.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some of the readings were quite interesting, but honestly not worth reading all of them. At most, multiple readings assigned for a class are only discussed for 20-30 min. Summaries were enough to get by. The class discussions didn't go in too deep and the professor did not guide the discussions. It all relied on the students. Also, both papers were not given a prompt or any sort of guidance in writing. I do not suggest this to be one of your first classes at Yale as it does not give support in showing what Yale quality writing is.

Strengths: Dialogue was engaging; I felt included the conversation and that I could experiment with my ideas in front of my teacher and peers who wanted to help me; the professor asked us very interesting questions and provided us with the theory and historical perspective necessary to come to our own conclusions; the professor offered very strong feedback on papers and provided ways to make our arguments stronger

Weaknesses: Because there was so much reading assignments, we had to skim over very critical material and left out important essays i.e. The Fire Next Time; a possible way to improve this is by limiting the amount of readings due per class to really hone in on that one material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, this is an excellent introduction into the humanities and allowed me to explore foundational texts through an interesting lens

Yes because it offers wide-ranging discussion that every person should have in order to form compassionate relationships with others. Additionally, it provided so much valuable theoretical knowledge in one course, allowing students to identify their favorite interests to pursue them later.
